text: What is to sell?
Vendre.
Clearly, as it's pronounced so differently, vendre does not end in ER.
Vendre is spelt V-E-N-D, as in vend, R-E.
It's one of that sandre group of verbs, the ones that end in dr, as in sandre.
Now, the vast majority of verbs in French end in ER, around 90%.
And so that means that around 90% of the verbs in French are incredibly easy to use in the past tense,
because they sound just the same as they do.
When you are saying something like to eat, to prepare, they sound the same.
Let's have a practice with a couple of those before looking at Vendre more closely.
So, what is to buy?
Acheter.
And we have bought?
Nous avons acheté.
How about we have bought it?
Again, as you can see, to buy is acheté.
And bought is also acheté.
What is to eat?
Manger.
And we have eaten?
We have eaten it.
We have eaten it.
We have eaten it.
We have eaten it.
So as you can see, these ER verbs, which make up 90% of the verbs in French,
are very, very easy to change into the past.
You simply replace the ER with the cafe E and you have the past tense.
Let's look at vendre though.
Vendre doesn't end in ER.
And so when you use it in the past tense,
the ER cannot be replaced by cafe E because there is no ER.
There are also a number of other verbs where this situation is exactly the same.
For instance, what is to see?
Voir, which is spelt V-O-I-R.
There is no ER at the end.
And so it can't be replaced by cafe E.
So if you want to say I have seen,
well, we can't simply replace the ER with a cafe E because there is none.
However, it's not that difficult actually to use these either.
One of the things we can use is a phrase that exists in English,
which you may be familiar with.
Can you think of a phrase that we often use when we feel we've seen something before,
we feel we've encountered it.
We feel that perhaps just a moment ago,
we thought that was going to happen or it already happened.
Are you familiar with that term?
We often pronounce that in English as déjà vu.
We say, I've had some déjà vu.
And that literally, that's from French and it means already seen.
However, our pronunciation of it in English is a little peculiar
because vous means, of course, you.
So if we say déjà vu, it means already you,
which is quite peculiar.
This is simply because of a mispronunciation.
Do you remember, what's the informal word for the informal you?
What is you in French?
The informal one.
Tu.
The key vowel sound in this is,
obviously we have the sound oo in English,
but the essential vowel sound that's being used here is
yu, yu.
So for the informal you, it is of course tu, tu.
It's a vowel sound that doesn't exist in English,
but you can add it, you can add it onto any letter
and the French will use it for various things.
For instance,
to see is
voir
and already seen, as we are pronouncing it déjà vu,
we need to change the pronunciation of that vowel sound
to the same vowel sound that's used on the t to say you,
the tu.
So let's add the vowel sound, the yu,
onto the v for voir
and find seen.
So déjà vu should correctly be pronounced
déjà vu
déjà vu
So how would you say I have seen?
J'ai vu
You have seen
You may start to notice the difference between
vous and vu
just as the French do.
They don't sound the same.
You have yu, which is vu,
and then seen, which is vu.
Now, this way of changing a verb happens quite a lot in French.
The e-r verbs in the past will normally take the café-e.
But there's a large group that instead of taking a café-e in the past,
this is a large group of non-er verbs,
which will take this yu sound, yu, onto the end.
So they will replace the r or the re or whatever at the end with an u.
Now remind me, what is to sell?
Vendre
So, getting rid of the re at the end and exchanging them for our u sound,
which the easiest way to make that is to round your lips
and simply say e.
So your lips round as though to whistle,
but keeping them in that position to say e,
which will come out as u.
U.
Let's add that onto the n.
So get rid of the re from vendre.
How we say sold.
Vendu
Vendu
I have sold
J'ai vendu
We have sold
Nous avons vendu
We have sold it
Nous l'avons vendu
Thank you.
